procedure: Right hip cephalomedullary nail fixation for unstable intertrochanteric fracture

extracted_info.summary: 82-year-old male with history of HTN, Dementia, DM2, multinodular goiter, frequent falls, and nephrolithiasis who suffered an unwitnessed fall with head strike. Patient presents with right hip pain and inability to bear weight. X-ray shows right unstable intertrochanteric fracture. Plan is for surgical intervention with hip cephalomedullary nail.
key_information: Patient is from skilled nursing facility (Nathaniel Witherall ECF)
Patient's cousin Paul is healthcare proxy
History of frequent falls
Non-weight bearing on right lower extremity
Consent obtained for surgery
Patient has history of left radial fracture (2023)
Lisinopril allergy (cough)
PCP: Walsh, Francis X 203-661-9433
Patient admitted from ED on 1/3/2026
Diabetes with hyperglycemia noted during hospitalization

procedure: Right hip cephalomedullary nail fixation for unstable intertrochanteric fracture
extracted_info.summary: 82-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including HTN, dementia, DM2, and history of falls presented with a right unstable intertrochanteric hip fracture. Patient underwent right hip cephalomedullary nail fixation with a 125-degree x 10mm x 420mm Arthrex nail, including placement of a 110mm lag screw, 95mm derotation screw, and 48mm distal interlock screw. The procedure was complicated by comminution of both greater and lesser trochanters, requiring additional fixation with a derotation screw for stability.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

| had a very long and thorough discussion with the patient's cousin Paul, who is his healthcare proxy, regarding this
injury and its treatment options. Given the patient's previous functional status, goals, and injury, | did present surgical
intervention as an option to treat this injury. Surgical intervention would take the form of a hip cephalomedullary nail.
The patient understands that conservative treatment for this injury is an option, and would consist of
nonweightbearing of the injured lower extremity for approximately 6 weeks while the fracture heals. They understand
that conservative treatment is associated with higher risks of nonunion, malunion, prolonged immobility, the sequelae
of prolonged immobility such as ulcers and blood clots, and increased pain. They also understand that the risks
associated with surgery, which are described below, are not present with nonoperative treatment. They do
understand that surgery would allow for near immediate mobilization with physical therapy. | made it clear that
nonoperative treatment of hip fractures is typically associated with an approximately 89% mortality rate at 1 year.

The risks, benefits, and alternatives to surgery were discussed at length with the patient's cousin Paul, who is his
healthcare proxy, today over the phone. Risks discussed include but are not limited to bleeding, infection,
neurovascular injury, anesthesia risks, wound healing problems, failure to alleviate pain, new pain, stiffness,
nonunion, malunion, symptomatic hardware, hardware failure, arthritis, recurrent deformity, recurrent instability,
inability to return to previous level of activity, medical complications, the need for more surgery in the future, loss of
limb, and loss of life. Specifically, complications and loss of life is a significant risk of undergoing this procedure. The
patient's cousin understood this. No guarantees were given. All questions were answered. After this discussion, the
patient's cousin Paul , who is his healthcare proxy, chose to proceed with surgical intervention.

Pre-operative Diagnosis: Right hip unstable intertrochanteric fracture
Post-operative Diagnosis: Right hip unstable intertrochanteric fracture
Surgeon: Jordan B Pasternack, MD

Assistants: N/A

Anesthesia: General endotracheal anesthesia

ASA Class: 3

Procedure Details
Implants:

Arthrex Nail - 125 degree x 10mm x 420mm
Derotation screw - 95mm

Lag screw - 110mm

Distal interlock(s) - 48mm

The patient was identified in their hospital room. Consent was verified. The appropriate extremity, which was the
right lower extremity, was marked.

The patient was brought to the operating room. General anesthesia was administered. The patient was transferred
supine to the Hana table. All bony prominences were well padded. A well-padded perineal post was placed. The feet
and ankles were wrapped in Webril and Coban and placed into traction boots. The operative lower extremity was

Ipekdjian, George (MRN MR408906) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 1/5/2026 9:12 AM

1/5/26, 9:12 AM Ipekdjian, George (MR # MR408906) DOB: 09/26/1943

placed into straight longitudinal alignment and slight adduction. The contralateral lower extremity was also placed
into straight longitudinal alignment, in slight abduction and hip extension to facilitate obtaining fluoroscopic images of
the operative extremity. The fracture site was identified and reduced into a satisfactory, reduced position on both AP
and lateral fluoroscopic images. Consistent with preoperative imaging, there was comminution of both the greater
and lesser trochanters. The operative extremity was prepped and draped in normal sterile fashion with a
chlorhexidine scrub brush followed by chlorhexidine surgical prep. Appropriate time was given for the prep to dry,
and appropriate antibiotics were given within 1 hour of the start of the procedure. Surgical time-out was performed.

The longitudinal axis of the femur as well as the level of the greater trochanter were marked on the sterile drape. An
incision approximately % of an inch in length was made about 2 fingerbreadths proximal to the tip of the greater
trochanter as demonstrated fluoroscopically. Dissection was carried down to the subcutaneous tissue along the line
of the incision. The fascia was then opened in line with the incision but distal to the incision. The greater trochanter
was able to be palpated manually at this point. A guidewire was used to establish the correct trajectory down the tip
of the greater trochanter in line with the proximal metaphysis of the femur. Correct position of this wire was verified
using orthogonal fluoroscopic views. The opening Reamer was utilized. A 3.0 mm ball-tipped guidewire was then
placed down the femoral canal to the level of the physeal scar. Appropriate position of this wire distally was
confirmed using orthogonal fluoroscopic views. A depth gauge was used to measure the appropriate length of the
nail.

The nail was then inserted into the femoral canal with the jig facing anterior, and then gradually being lowered into
the lateral position as the nail progressed to match the bow of the femur. The nail was inserted to appropriate depth
as confirmed on fluoroscopic imaging. Next, a separate stab incision was made for another guidewire to be placed
through a triple sleeve into approximately the center center position of the femoral head. A depth gauge was inserted
to the level of bone to ascertain the appropriate length of lag screw.

Given the extensive comminution of the fracture, so a derotation screw was placed into the femoral head through the
jig superior to the lag screw guidewire for extra fixation. The lag screw incision was extended proximally, and the
derotation trocar was placed. A drill was then used to drill for the derotation screw, and then the screw was inserted.

The lag screw guidewire was then over-reamed, with care taken to not enter into the hip joint itself.

The lag screw was then inserted over its guidewire. Traction was then removed from the operative extremity and
compression of the fracture was performed utilizing the compression sleeve on the jig. Appropriate compression of
the fracture was confirmed using fluoroscopy.

Following this, the derotation screw was then final tightened, as fracture compression resulted in the derotation screw
becoming slightly proud.

Then one distal interlock screw was placed into the nail in the static hole. Perfect circle technique was used to place
this distal interlock as follows: a perfect lateral of the distal end of the nail was obtained. An incision was made in the
center of the static hole. A clamp was used to spread bluntly to bone in both planes. A drill bit was positioned so that
the tip was in the center of the hole, confirmed using two fluoroscopic views in which the drill bit was positioned in
orthogonal planes with respect to the xray beam. The drill was then positioned in line with the C-arm and drilled
across the near femoral cortex, through the nail, and just past the far femoral cortex. The screw length was then
measured off of the drill bit. The drill was removed and the screw inserted with appropriate purchase obtained as the
screw was seated down to bone.

Next, orthogonal fluoroscopic views demonstrated appropriate position of the distal interlock screw, the fracture, the
proximal nail, and the lag screw. At this point, the procedure was accepted.

All incisions were washed out with copious sterile normal saline from a bulb syringe. The proximal wound underwent
a layered fashion closure, with 0 Vicryl figure-of-eight sutures to close the fascia, 2-0 Vicryl for subcutaneous tissue,
and staples for skin. The other incisions were closed with 2-0 Vicryl for the subcutaneous tissue and staples for skin.
RECK solution was injected around the skin incisions for pain relief. Dermabond was then placed over the wounds.
Sterile dressings were applied. The patient was then awoken from anesthesia and transferred off the operating room
table in stable condition. Final counts were correct.

They also understand that the risks associated with surgery, which are described below, are not present with nonoperative treatment. They do understand that surgery would allow for near immediate mobilization with physical therapy. I made it clear that nonoperative treatment of hip fractures is typically associated with an approximately 89% mortality rate at 1 year.

[AI ADDED: Medical Necessity Documentation: Surgical intervention with hip cephalomedullary nail is medically necessary due to:
1. Unstable intertrochanteric fracture pattern
2. Patient's inability to bear weight
3. Significant pain with movement
4. High risk of complications with non-operative management including mortality
5. Potential for improved functional outcome and earlier mobilization with surgical fixation]

The risks, benefits, and alternatives to surgery were discussed at length with the patient's cousin Paul, who is his healthcare proxy, today over the phone. Risks discussed include but are not limited to bleeding, infection, neurovascular injury, anesthesia risks, wound healing problems, failure to alleviate pain, new pain, stiffness, nonunion, malunion, symptomatic hardware, hardware failure, arthritis, recurrent deformity, recurrent instability, inability to return to previous level of activity, medical complications, the need for more surgery in the future, loss of limb, and loss of life. Specifically, complications and loss of life is a significant risk of undergoing this procedure. The patient's cousin understood this. No guarantees were given. All questions were answered. After this discussion, the patient's cousin Paul, who is his healthcare proxy, chose to proceed with surgical intervention.

- Non-weight bearing right lower extremity
- NPO/IVF
- DVT prophylaxis: hold chemical prophylaxis for OR today, venodynes
- Pain control: Oxycodone 5mg as needed for moderate pain; Tylenol for mild pain
- Colace 100mg BID while taking oxycodone
- Zofran PRN while taking oxycodone
- Resume Home Medications
- Preoperative labs: CBC, BMP, PT/PTT and INR, T&S, CXR, EKG. These are completed.
- Preoperative medical optimization by hospitalist, this is completed
- Medical comanagement by hospitalist, recommendations appreciated
- OR today for hip cephalomedullary nail. Consent obtained
- Follow-up MRSA screen

[AI ADDED: Post-operative Plan:
- Physical therapy evaluation on post-operative day 1
- Occupational therapy evaluation for ADL assessment
- Anticipated discharge to skilled nursing facility for rehabilitation
- Follow-up appointment in orthopedic clinic in 2 weeks for wound check and radiographic evaluation
- Subsequent follow-up at 6 weeks post-operatively for clinical and radiographic assessment of healing]

Patient's cousin understood and agreed with this plan. All questions were answered.

extraction_data.summary: 82-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including HTN, dementia, DM2, and history of falls presented with a right unstable intertrochanteric hip fracture. Patient underwent right hip cephalomedullary nail fixation with a 125-degree x 10mm x 420mm Arthrex nail, including placement of a 110mm lag screw, 95mm derotation screw, and 48mm distal interlock screw. The procedure was complicated by comminution of both greater and lesser trochanters, requiring additional fixation with a derotation screw for stability.
